item.title: Tiburon plans $6.43 mil in projects
item.description: About $1.06 million is earmarked for parks improvements as the town begins implementing its long-term vision for parks, recreation and open spaces.
item.content:encoded:
Tiburon plans to spend $6.43 million on capital-improvement projects in the 2025-2026 fiscal year, with about $1.06 million earmarked for parks improvements as the town begins implementing its long-term vision for parks, recreation and open spaces.

Among the projects are fixing Tiburon’s steps, lanes and paths; replacing the bridge along the Old Rail Trail toward downtown Tiburon; adding wayfinding signs throughout the town; rehabbing Lyford Tower’s roof; and an early $200,000 commitment toward overall parks amenities and improvements.

The Planning Commission reviewed the capital-improvement program May 28 and voted 3-0 to find it conforms with Tiburon’s general plan. Chair Kathleen Defever and Vice Chair Daniel Amir were absent.

The Town Council will review the program tonight, June 4, as part of the wider budget review for the new fiscal year, which starts July 1. The council is expected to adopt the budget, including capital projects, June 18.
item.dc:creator: Francisco Martinez

item.title: Meeting tonight: Caltrans bike lanes
item.description: The forum comes amid mounting criticism over safety and communications concerns regarding the controversial project.
item.content:encoded:
Caltrans officials will address public concerns aboutplanned bike laneson Tiburon Boulevard at a special meeting with the Town Council and Southern Marin Supervisor Stephanie Moulton-Peters from 5 to 6:30 tonight, June 4, at Town Hall.

The forum comes amid mounting criticism over safety and communications concerns regarding the controversial project.Local agenciesandAssemblymember Damon Connollyhave raised issues about traffic congestion, school-bus service disruptions and emergency-response impacts.

Residents can attend the meeting at Town Hall, 1505 Tiburon Blvd., or join via Zoom or by phone at 669-444-9171 with meeting ID 892-1708-7066. The Town Council’s regular meeting will follow.

item.title: Tiburon up for nearly $600K sea-rise grant as climate work expands
item.description: Tiburon’s top sustainability official says she believes the town is still on track to meet its ambitious goal of reducing emissions to...
item.content:encoded:
Tiburon’s top sustainability official says she believes the town is still on track to meet its ambitious goal of reducing emissions to 50% below 1990 levels, but residents will need to pivot away from gas-powered vehicles and appliances.

Grace Ledwith, the shared climate action and sustainability coordinator for Tiburon and Mill Valley, delivered her annual update on Tiburon’s Climate Action Plan at the Town Council’s May 21 meeting.

The 126-page plan, adopted in September 2022, outlines strategies, time frames, staffing resources, greenhouse-gas reductions and key metrics with its emission-reduction goal — stronger than the 40% reduction set by the state in 2016. That will require slashing 21,000 metric tons of carbon emissions.

Ledwith said two of the big actions that can help Tiburon meet its goal are “really getting folks out of their single-occupancy gas-powered vehicles” and having people switch from gas- to electric-powered appliances.

item.title: Tiburon police to stick with detective role after trial run
item.description: “We’ve had great success solving three or four major cases,” Police Chief Michelle Jean said.
item.content:encoded:
The Tiburon Police Department has officially resurrected its long-vacant detective role after a six-month trial in which the sergeant serving in the position helped make arrests in a robbery case of CVS/pharmacy and a serial shoplifting case at Nugget Market, among others, officials say.

Sgt. Rob Law will stay in the role indefinitely, though it will remain a specialty assignment rather than a permanent position within the force, Capt. Jarrod Yee said in an email. Law will retain his position as sergeant, one of the department’s four, while continuing to earn special assignment pay of $315 per month, or $3,780 per year, which he has been receiving since he took on the role in January.

“We’ve had great success solving three or four major cases,” Police Chief Michelle Jean said at a May 20 meeting of her Citizens Advisory Panel.

item.title: Parents and teachers divided over cost and value of canceled camp
item.description: Bel Aire Elementary School will not participate in The Mosaic Project this fall, ending a 16-year partnership that costs the school district more than $100,000 annually.
item.content:encoded:
Bel Aire Elementary School will not participate in The Mosaic Project this fall, ending a 16-year partnership with the diversity camp program that costs the school district more than $100,000 annually.

The decision has divided the school community, with dozens of parents and community members packing a contentious May 29 meeting to debate the four-day camp program for fourth graders.

The Mosaic Project gathers students from schools across the Bay Area for what the nonprofit describes as an effort to “bring together students from diverse backgrounds to reduce prejudice and promote peace,” according to a May 4 Reed Union School District newsletter.

item.media:description: Kids wave signs outside Bel Aire Elementary School on May 29 in support of The Mosaic Project, a four-day day camp that brings students from different backgrounds together to promote diversity and peace. (Tyler Callister / The Ark)

item.title: Court: Belvedere must redo $300k construction-penalty decision
item.description: The court found that the Belvedere’s decision-making process lacked sufficient factual findings to justify upholding the maximum penalty.
item.content:encoded:
A Marin Superior Court judge has ordered the Belvedere City Council to reconsider its decision to impose a $300,000 construction time-limit penalty on the owner of a luxury home-remodel project, ruling that its findings were inadequate to support the fine.

Judge Andrew E. Sweet issued the ruling May 27 in the case involving 339 Golden Gate Ave. homeowners David and Julie Flaherty, who sued the city in October 2022 as Golden Gate Belvedere LLC. The court found that the Belvedere’s decision-making process lacked sufficient factual findings to justify upholding the maximum penalty and remanded the matter back to the council while retaining jurisdiction over the case.

“The lack of any subfindings leaves fundamental questions about the basis for the city’s decision unanswered,” Sweet wrote in his 23-page ruling. “The court is at a loss as to how to test the city’s findings against the evidence, given that the findings provide no information about what evidence played a role in the city’s decision.”
item.dc:creator: Kevin Hessel

item.title: Tiburon police explore tech to cut paperwork, track officer performance
item.description: The department activated a 90-day trial of Barricade AI, software that analyzes camera footage and automatically generates police reports.
item.content:encoded:
The Tiburon Police Department is testing artificial intelligence software that converts body camera footage into police reports and exploring a second system to track officer performance.

Last month, the department activated a 90-day free trial of Barricade AI, software developed by a Mountain View company that analyzes camera footage and automatically generates police reports similar to how ChatGPT processes text, according to a presentation at the chief’s Citizens Advisory Panel meeting May 20.

Seven full-time officers are now using Barricade AI, which analyzes officer movements, incident timing and location data from body-cam and dash-cam footage. The software then creates narrative reports that officers must review and approve before filing.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Callister

item.title: Former Citizen of the Year Emeritus Vera Gertler was crucial member of GreenTeam
item.description: Longtime Belvedere resident Vera Gertler died May 14 in San Francisco following an illness.
item.content:encoded:
Longtime Belvedere resident Vera Gertler, who was honored as the city’s Citizen of the Year Emeritus in 2013 for her role in organizing the volunteer effort to beautify the medians along Tiburon Boulevard, died May 14 in San Francisco following an illness. She was 91.

Gertler, who lived in Belvedere for more than two decades, was a “super force” and critical in the early days of the Tiburon Peninsula GreenTeam and one of its predecessor organizations, the Beautify Tiburon Boulevard Committee, GreenTeam member Jerry Riessen said. The beautification committee was founded in 1996 with the goal of restoring boulevard medians to their 1976 state, when Caltrans had planted red photinia, white oleander and blue rosemary to celebrate the U.S. bicentennial.

“All of our meetings were at her house, and that’s where we organized ourselves,” Riessen said, adding that he has “very fond and great appreciation for all of her hard work.”

Gertler spent nine years, from July 2007 to June 2016, as Belvedere’s representative on the Marin County Commission on Aging, the advisory council that advocates on behalf of older adults to the Marin Board of Supervisors. During her tenure on the commission, Gertler served on the housing-and-transportation and planning-and-communications committees, said Gary Lara, an administrative assistant with the Marin County Health and Human Services Department and the staff liaison to the commission.

Gertler was born Vera Lutomirski on June 23, 1933, in Milan, Italy, to Simon Lutomirski and Gerda Boehm. She was the second of four children, born after brother Ernesto and before sisters Gabriella and Eva.

Her parents divorced when she was young, and her mother took her and her sisters to Portugal before settling in Zurich, Switzerland, after escaping the Holocaust. During World War II, Boehm started a business sending out care packages with food, clothing and blankets to prisoners in concentration camps.

Gertler went on to receive a nursing degree in Geneva. Son Peter Gertler of Oakland said Gertler originally wanted to be an interior designer but was dissuaded by her own mom, who said it wasn’t a job for women.

However, nursing proved to be a good fit, he said.

“She was a natural at it because she loved to take care of people,” Peter said. “That was her sort of M.O., you know, even later in life.”

item.title: Tiburon woman helps set world record by 44 seconds at track meet
item.description: Simmons ran lead-off in 2:47.6, the fastest leg of the relay.
item.content:encoded:
Tiburon residentNancy Simmonshelped her four-woman relay team set a pending world record in the women’s 65-69 age group 4x800-meter relay at the Down the Stretch Track Fest at George Mason University in Fairfax, Virginia, on May 24.

The Impala Racing Team, consisting of Simmons, Cheryl Bellaire, Julie Hayden and Lesley Hinz, completed the race in 11:47.94, shattering the previous world record of 12:31.46 set last year in St. Paul, Minnesota, by nearly 44 seconds.

Simmons ran lead-off in 2:47.6, the fastest leg of the relay.

The 4x800-meter event requires each runner to complete two laps around a standard 400-meter track. The team consisted of the top four U.S. women over 65 from the World Championships in Gainesville, Florida.

Simmons has been featured in The Ark previously for her competitive running achievements.

item.title: Everyday Encounters: A new couple bonds over their shared love of food
item.description: The couple, who have been dating since August, say they enjoy date night at local restaurants such as Servino Trattoria, Malibu Farm and The Bungalow Kitchen, but they also love cooking together.
item.content:encoded:
Tiburon residents Eric Hagerman and Alfiya Nachtigall say food is their shared love language.

The couple, who have been dating since August, say they enjoy date night at local restaurants such as Servino Trattoria, Malibu Farm and The Bungalow Kitchen, but they also love cooking together, with Hagerman turning up the heat in the kitchen.

He says he previously took classes at the now-closed Tante Marie’s Cooking School in North Beach to both improve his own cooking skill and to impress others.

“You can’t just show up and say, ‘What’s for dinner?’” Hagerman says as he and Nachtigall take Teddy, their 11-month-old cavapoo, for a walk at Shoreline Park on May 27. “You got to say, ‘Hey, look what I made!’”
item.dc:creator: Francisco Martinez
item.media:description: Tiburon residents Eric Hagerman and Alfiya Nachtigall take Teddy, an 11-month-old cavapoo, for a walk along Shoreline Park on May 27. The two longtime friends have been dating since August. (Francisco Martinez / The Ark)

item.title: Garden Plot: Native plant society offers education, volunteer opportunities
item.description: The organization has a plethora of activities and learning experiences in and around the county’s amazing native-plant communities.
item.content:encoded:
If you have space on your calendar to be involved in an organization, you might consider joining the Marin chapter of the California Native Plant Society. The organization has a plethora of activities and learning experiences in and around the county’s amazing native-plant communities. Visitcnpsmarin.orgto learn more.

The monthly chapter meeting is at 7:30 p.m. June 9 via Zoom, featuring Meg Marriott, a wildlife biologist with U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Marriott will talk about Marin Islands National Wildlife Refuge, an unpopulated reserve that serves as the largest heron and egret rookery in the Bay Area.

While the islands are not open to the public, volunteers can participate in stewardship activities. Participants take a motorboat from Loch Lomond in San Rafael to work on conservation tasks. This sounds like so much fun; I don’t qualify, as I clomp around on my walking stick, but you might.

item.title: Pick of the Week: Charged Particles playing jazz June 8 at Old St. Hilary’s
item.description: Charged Particles jazz trio featuring saxophonist Tod Dickow will play a concert 4 p.m. June 8 at Old St. Hilary’s Landmark.
item.content:encoded: Charged Particles jazz trio featuring saxophonist Tod Dickow will play a concert 4 p.m. June 8 at Old St. Hilary’s Landmark. They will be playing the music of late saxophone great Michael Brecker, the composer and bandleader who won 15 Grammys from the 1970s to his death in 2007. Tickets are $20-$25 in advance online or at the Landmarks Society office, $25-$30 at the door if not sold out. There is no parking at Old St. Hilary’s Landmark; free parking is at The Boardwalk shopping center, with a shuttle running from in front of Rustic Bakery beginning half an hour before the show. 415-435-1853 orlandmarkssociety.com.

item.title: Town to hold first Native American festival in June
item.description: Native American food dishes, interactive exhibits and a drum troupe powwow will be part of Tiburon’s newest cultural celebration coming to Zelinsky Park.
item.content:encoded:
Native American food dishes, interactive exhibits and a drum troupe powwow will be part of Tiburon’s newest cultural celebration coming to Zelinsky Park, tentatively set for June 21, the day before the town’s fifth annual Juneteenth festival on lower Main Street.

The Town Council approved nearly $20,000 in funding for both events, voting 4-0-1 to grant $6,000 for the Native American heritage festival and $13,497 for Juneteenth; Vice Mayor Jon Welner abstained over ballooning cost concerns for the latter event. Earlier in the evening, the Diversity Inclusion Task Force recommended approval of the funding in 8-0 vote, with one vacancy and at-large appointee Nooshin Navidi Latour absent.
item.dc:creator: Francisco Martinez

item.title: Caltrans to address bike-lane plan at special forum
item.description: Assemblymember Damon Connolly, D-San Rafael, urged Caltrans to pause advancement of the controversial project.
item.content:encoded:
Caltrans officials will address mounting public concerns about planned bike lanes on Tiburon Boulevard at a special meeting with the Town Council and Southern Marin Supervisor Stephanie Moulton-Peters from 5 to 6:30 p.m. June 4 at Town Hall.

The forum comes as Assemblymember Damon Connolly, D-San Rafael, urged Caltrans to pause advancement of the controversial project, citing safety concerns and insufficient community engagement in a May 19 letter to the state transportation agency.

“Our residents and stakeholders will have an opportunity to discuss this very important project with Caltrans,” Mayor Holli Thier said in an email. “Caltrans will address the multiple safety and other concerns expressed and will discuss the path forward.”

item.title: Noise rules at Art & Garden Center tightened following neighbor appeal
item.description: The Tiburon Town Council partially granted an appeal from the so-called Art & Garden Neighborhood Collective.
item.content:encoded:
The Belvedere-Tiburon Landmarks Society will have to get third-party monitoring if it wants to keep using amplified music for Art & Garden Center events after neighbors appealed the venue’s conditional-use permit.

The Tiburon Town Council voted unanimously to implement the requirement during a May 21 hearing that extended past midnight, partially granting an appeal from the so-called Art & Garden Neighborhood Collective. The group of seven neighbors living near the center, at 841 Tiburon Blvd., sought stricter noise controls for events with amplified music, primarily weddings.
item.dc:creator: Francisco Martinez
item.media:description: The Belvedere-Tiburon Landmarks Society’s Art & Garden Center in Tiburon is a popular wedding venue, but the nonprofit historical society was operating without a permit for amplified music for nearly three decades. Neighbors partially won an appeal of the new permit, requiring third-party monitoring to ensure decibel levels don’t exceed 60 at the property line. (Yuliya Jul Photography via Belvedere-Tiburon Landmarks Society)

item.title: Reed district honors teachers, staff at end-of-year ceremony
item.description: First-grade teacher Patty Ryan was named the Reed Union School District’s Teacher of the Year for 2024-2025.
item.content:encoded:
Reed Elementary School first-grade teacher Patty Ryan is known among her colleagues as humble, soft-spoken and compassionate, said Principal Mary Niesyn.

Ryan already has 25 years of teaching at Reed under her belt but is hoping for enough to become a “grand-teacher,” Niesyn said, which means having a student in her class who is the child of a former student.

For her efforts, Ryan was named the Reed Union School District’s Teacher of the Year for 2024-2025. She was one of more than a dozen teachers, classified staff and retirees honored at the district’s year-end Celebration of Education, which was held May 21 at St. Stephen’s Episcopal Church in Belvedere.

item.title: Tiburon OKs $1.8M to repave Paradise Drive stretch near downtown
item.description: Repaving will start at the intersection with Mar West Street and end at town limits near Agreste Way.
item.content:encoded:
Tiburon plans to spend up to $1.81 million to repave a half-mile stretch of Paradise Drive, with work tentatively set to begin in late June.

The 2,800 linear feet of repaving will start at the intersection with Mar West Street and end at town limits near Agreste Way. The work includes replacing curbs, gutters, sidewalks, curb ramps and valley gutters, pruning and removing tree roots and replacing traffic striping and pavement markings.

The project, part of Tiburon’s capital-improvement program for fiscal year 2025-2026, is scheduled to last 45 working days, Public Works Engineering Director David Eshoo said in an email.
item.dc:creator: Francisco Martinez

item.title: Everyday Encounters: A finance exec finds his ideal family life in Belvedere
item.description: Mario Valente, a former member of Belvedere’s Parks, Open Spaces and Lanes Committee, serves as deputy chief investment officer with Stansberry Asset Management.
item.content:encoded:
Mario Valente moved to Belvedere seven years ago seeking excellent schools and waterfront living for his family. The 49-year-old chief investment officer says he found both.

Valente, his wife and their three daughters relocated from Southern California, drawn by the community’s reputation and educational opportunities.

“We were looking for a family-friendly community, and Belvedere exceeded our expectations,” Valente says.

item.title: Crib Notes: Belvedere villa with yacht asks $22 million
item.description: A Mediterranean villa with San Francisco skyline views hit the market with an 800-square-foot guest house, a “hillevator” — and a 51-foot yacht.
item.content:encoded:
A 5,100-square-foot Mediterranean villa with San Francisco skyline views hit the market last month for $22 million, complete with an 800-square-foot guest house, a “hillevator” — and a 51-foot yacht.

The waterfront estate at 125 Belvedere Ave., on the backside of Belvedere Island, was built in 1978 and fully remodeled in 2007 by architect Andrew Skurman. Known as “Casa dei Sogni,” Italian for “the house of dreams,” the property mirrors the design of Belvedere’s official sister city, Portofino, Italy.
